node.title: Chinese state media says Peng Shuai will appear 'soon', amid speculation over missing tennis star
node.alt: Chinese tennis star Peng Shuai hits a tennis ball during practice at the Australian Open in 2019.
node.description: Chinese state media employees post photos of missing sportswoman Peng Shuai, saying she is at home and "didn't want to be disturbed".
node.content: ["Chinese state media employees have sought to reassure the world that missing tennis star Peng Shuai is safe and well, after global concern for her whereabouts.", "Peng has not been active in public since she accused a former top Communist party official, Zhang Gaoli, of rape more than two weeks ago.", "Since then, China's Foreign Ministry has said it is not aware of the controversy.", "The 35-year-old former top-ranked player in women's doubles won titles at Wimbledon in 2013 and the French Open in 2014.", "Peng also participated in three Olympics, and her disappearance is getting more attention as Beijing prepares to host the Winter Games starting on February 4.", "Early on Saturday, Shen Shiwei from\u00a0CGTN,the English-language arm of China Central Television that is aimed at foreign audiences, posted photos of a seemingly happy Peng Shuai on Twitter, which is officially blocked in China.", "The state TV employee wrote they were posted on Peng's account on Chinese messaging\u00a0service\u00a0WeChat with the comment, \u201cHappy Weekend\u201d.", "The photos showed Peng with a grey cat and holding a panda figurine in what appeared to be a private home, with stuffed animals lined up behind her.", "There was no indication when the photos were taken.\u00a0", "After widespread skepticism on social media and demands that Peng appear in public in person, Editor-in-Chief of Chinese state-run tabloid Global Times. Hu Xijin. said he had confirmed the tweet through his \"own sources\".", "He said\u00a0she was staying in her own home \"freely\" and will make a public appearance \"soon\".", "Mr Shen's Twitter post came after CGTN distributed a statement earlier this week \u2014 which it said came from Peng \u2014 that retracted the accusations against Mr Zhang.", "The chairman and CEO of the Women's Tennis Association, Steve Simon, questioned the legitimacy of that\u00a0statement, saying it \"only raises my concerns as to her safety\".", "Peng wrote in a lengthy social media post on November 2 that she was forced to have sex three years ago with Mr Zhang\u00a0in his home despite repeated refusals.", "Mr Zhang, 75, is a former vice-premier who was a member of the ruling Communist Party's all-powerful Politburo Standing Committee.", "The post was quickly deleted from Peng's verified account on Weibo, a leading Chinese social media platform, but screenshots of the accusation were shared on the internet.", "AP/ABC"]
